body:
> commits should have been squashed

They were squashed, just not in the PR. I added a commit in my [own branch](https://github.com/julianhyde/calcite/tree/6759-order-offset), then squashed and merged to main when the tests pass.

It's a useful flow because it preserves the history of the dev branch, and allows the committer (me in this case) to copy-edit and add more tests.

> you can probably squash the commits

Done.

SonarQube Cloud integrates seamlessly into your GitHub workflow and provides clear guidance for resolving any code quality and security issues detected. The majority of popular languages can be analyzed automatically; no configuration is required!

With [SonarQube Cloud](https://sonarcloud.io/github), you get:

-   Fast, precise static analysis and feedback on your code
    
-   Support for popular languages, frameworks, and IaC tools
    
-   Free analysis for open-source projects and private projects up to max 50k LoC
    
-   Automatic analysis of pull requests and branches with results reported inline
    
-   IDE Support with [SonarQube for IDE](https://www.sonarsource.com/products/sonarlint/) integration
    
-   Quality Gate (added as a GitHub check) acting at two different levels - first, preventing you from merging pull requests that contain issues - and later, helping you to release only clean, safe code
    
-   Sign up for SonarQube free tier and begin scanning your private and public repositories

yes, I think this will be ready for merging once the commits are squashed
Squashed. Thanks for reviewing!
@asolimando I have pushed a commit which hopefully addresses your comments.
I will write a few more tests, so I will mark this PR as draft until I am sure it passes all of them. Hopefully this won't take too long.

I noticed that @herunkang2018 authored [3201](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/3201) for this case before.
It may be better to let him know and make sure he is OK with this.

> I noticed that @herunkang2018 authored [3201](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/3201) for this case before. It may be better to let him know and make sure he is OK with this.

I've added comments in jira [CALCITE-5626]

@mihaibudiu, Thanks for the review! In my opinion, such a change breaks too much. A good way would be to return null on correlation variable. For correlated origin, maybe add other metadataQuery. So I've changed the issue and will be adding a new PR.

> @asolimando I have pushed a commit which hopefully addresses your comments.

Thanks @mihaibudiu, LGTM, just proposed two improved test names, the rest is good, feel free to ping me for an extra review round once the extra tests are ready, if needed

The complete fix required some additions to the type factory interfaces and making a method public.
As I commented in the jira https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-6764, I think that the methods from the type factory to create nullable types are broken for record types.

body: In https://github.com/julianhyde/calcite/tree/5626-subquery-qualified I've made the test case in `SqlValidatorTest` more minimal, and I've added some more queries in `sub-query.iq`. Will merge shortly.
@asolimando I made some changes that probably will require a new review

@suibianwanwank, I noticed that GitHub is not tying your commits to your GitHub user. If you want to get credit for those commits (e.g. when we measure top contributors in Calcite) then you should fix the mapping. IIRC, it's based on email address in `git log`, so you should review the email address attached to your commits and/or tell GitHub that the email is one associated with your account.

> @suibianwanwank, I noticed that GitHub is not tying your commits to your GitHub user. If you want to get credit for those commits (e.g. when we measure top contributors in Calcite) then you should fix the mapping. IIRC, it's based on email address in `git log`, so you should review the email address attached to your commits and/or tell GitHub that the email is one associated with your account.

I recently had to do it for myself, you can check this [commit](https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/60953ecd9c055e0e029de0d6034037cc7d68361a) if needed. If you just need to link extra email addresses to your GitHub account, it suffices to add them in your GitHub profile and validate them.

Alessandro Solimando <18898964+asolimando@users.noreply.github.com>

body:
> @asolimando I thought that mailmap helps `git log` produce better output but didn't think it helps GitHub map commits to GitHub users. But does the line
> 
> ```
> Alessandro Solimando <18898964+asolimando@users.noreply.github.com>
> ```
> 
> achieve that mapping?

@julianhyde yes, apart from helping `git log` as you suggest, it is also used by GitHub itself to link multiple email addresses under the same account.

The `@users.noreply.github.com` one is necessarily linked to your GitHub account, but I suspect that it works also for every other email address registered *and* verified in your GitHub account, but I haven't tested that in isolation (i.e., without the `@users.noreply.github.com`), so I can't be 100% sure.

By mistake I have used "@apache.com" in one of my recent commits around Cassandra and I couldn't add this email address to GitHub as it couldn't be verified (because it's invalid).

Adding it to the .mailmap file allowed GitHub to compute the commit count correctly. Please note that it takes ~24h to update it.
PR and commit should match JIRA
Can you please rebase this on main to resolve the conflicts?
What is the conclusion from the JIRA discussion? Can we merge this?

> Can you please rebase this on main to resolve the conflicts?

sure, I'll do it later today/tomorrow

> How is this related to the CheckerFramework? I suspect that the JIRA title is wrong. Maybe there is a problem in the AbstractSqlTester, but that's unrelated.

You are right this is not about CheckerFramework. I'm considering changing the summary to `AbstractSqlTester failed to build query for expression TRIM(string)`. What do you think?
that is better, but I would say "fails" instead of "failed"
I don't think this is the correct fix. This method is also invoked by casts from strings to numeric, and there it must throw.

If the value is null, this method will return null; why cant it return null for an empty string as well? I believe the null check at the beginning was added precisely to prevent a NumberFormatException when creating a BigDecimal, wasnt it?
You can run the existing tests on your machine using `./gradlew build`, this will show that this fix breaks many other tests.

body: hi @NobiGo I agree with your point, but this CSV file is not prepared by developers or technical staff; it is provided by ordinary users who do not understand technology. We cannot demand that they define the type of each column, as this would lead to a poor user experience.

> hi @NobiGo I agree with your point, but this CSV file is not prepared by developers or technical staff; it is provided by ordinary users who do not understand technology. We cannot demand that they define the type of each column, as this would lead to a poor user experience.

Yes. I get your point. Can we explain the default data types in the document to help you with your worries? The current PR changes have already affected all semantics of other non-CSV SQL types, which is unacceptable.

Alright, then we can only process the file again after the user submits the document.

However, I dont quite understand why the charToDecimalCast() method only checks for null but not for an empty string. In what scenario would forcibly converting an empty string and then throwing an error be considered normal business logic? This is just a personal question, and Id like to seek your advice.
